Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may “make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parties” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties and that the modification is in the best interests of the child.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Since entry of the Existing Order on May 10, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the safety, welfare, and best interests of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and controlling case law, including but not limited to *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the earlier judgment, and it interprets and applies G.L. c. 208 in that context. While Schuler involves the sufficiency of financial changes rather than child safety per se, it is properly cited as controlling authority for the general legal standard that a material and substantial change in circumstances is required under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and related provisions) to warrant modification. Thus it supports the proposition about the need to show such a change since the prior order.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … An order for child support may be modified "as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require." G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1976, c. 279, § 1.

*Heistand v. *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the safety, welfare, and best interests of a minor child under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Heistand does discuss modification of child support under § 28 and the need for a demonstrated change in circumstances, but it does not address changes relating to the child’s safety, welfare, or best interests; rather, it focuses on an increase in the payor’s income as grounds for upward modification. Thus it supports the general change-in-circumstances standard for support modification, not the more specific safety/welfare/best-interests proposition for custody or parenting issues.
*Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant urges that the judgment requiring him to pay $20 more per child each week was unsupported by evidence of a material change in circumstances. In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). … Of the several factors which the judge may consider in modifying a decree for child support, G. L. c. 208, § 28, this court has never required that they be accorded equal weight or conjunctive application.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Since entry of the Existing Order on May 10, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the safety, welfare, and best interests of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and controlling case law, including but not limited to *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the Massachusetts standard for modifying an existing custody order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Custody of Vaughn is not a post‑judgment modification case and does not analyze or apply the ‘material and substantial change’ requirement; instead, it addresses what findings are required about domestic violence when initially awarding or structuring custody and remands for more detailed findings. While highly relevant to domestic-violence considerations in custody, it does not provide authority for the specific change‑in‑circumstances standard cited in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Since entry of the Existing Order on May 10, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the safety, welfare, and best interests of the minor child, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and controlling case law, including but not limited to *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Heistand v. Heistand*, 384 Mass. 20 (1981); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali concerns the initial custody determination for a nonmarital child under G.L. c. 209C, § 10, and explicitly declines to apply or discuss the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard that governs later modification proceedings under G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and, by analogy, G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court even notes that arguments about the modification standard were waived and instead applies the best-interests standard for an initial order. It therefore does not provide authority on what constitutes a post‑judgment material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s best interests under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child’s safety and well‑being are paramount in custody determinations and that the Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material change of circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.support_reasoning: The case squarely states the governing standard for modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be necessary in the best interests of the child. The opinion further emphasizes that Probate and Family Court judges have broad discretion to fashion orders that protect the interests and welfare of minor children, reflecting that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody determinations. Thus it directly supports the proposition as to both the standard and the primacy of the child’s welfare.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child’s safety and well‑being are paramount in custody determinations and that the Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material change of circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does emphasize protection of children and the child’s welfare as a basis for State intervention, but it is a care‑and‑protection case between a parent and the State, not a custody or parenting‑time modification case between parents. It does not discuss the standard for modifying existing custody or parenting time based on a material change in circumstances, nor does it frame the analysis in terms of an ongoing “best interests” modification standard. Thus it cannot be accurately cited for the specific proposition about modification of custody/parenting time upon material change and best interests of the child.
*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Pursuant to the statutory provision creating the action, G. L. c. 119, § 24… If the court finds the allegations proved, the judge may commit the child to the department until the minor becomes eighteen years of age or the judge may make any other order deemed appropriate to the child’s best interests. G. L. c. 119, § 26.… State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.”

*Custody of a Minor (No. 2)*, 392 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child’s safety and well‑being are paramount in custody determinations and that the Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material change of circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Custody of a Minor (No. 2)*, 392 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion emphasizes that custody and visitation decisions must be guided by the child’s welfare, and that removal from a parent requires clear and convincing proof of parental unfitness and specific findings that visits would harm the child. However, the case is a care-and-protection proceeding about initial/permanent custody and termination of visitation, not a post‑judgment modification case, and it does not discuss the ‘material change of circumstances’ standard for modifying existing custody or parenting-time orders. Thus it supports the broad idea that the child’s welfare is paramount, but not the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Custody of a Minor (No. 2)*, 392 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “A judge is required to exercise utmost care in custody proceedings and must make ‘specific and detailed findings demonstrating that close attention has been given the evidence and that the necessity of removing the child from his or her parents has been persuasively shown.’ … We next turn to the mother’s contention that her visitation rights were improperly terminated. … [B]efore terminating visitation rights, a judge must make specific findings demonstrating that parental visits will harm the child or the public welfare.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child’s safety and well‑being are paramount in custody determinations and that the Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material change of circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that in Massachusetts custody determinations the ‘overriding concern’ and ‘sole question’ is the best interests, happiness, and welfare of the children, so it supports that portion of the proposition about the child’s safety and well‑being being paramount. However, the case is an initial divorce/custody judgment and a modification of visitation from a temporary order, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding, and it does not articulate or apply a ‘material change of circumstances’ standard for modifying custody or parenting time. Thus it does not support the specific rule that the court may modify custody/parenting time upon a showing of a material change plus best interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … [I]n determining the question of custody ‘the rights of the parents shall … be held to be equal.’ … [T]he Supreme Judicial Court … added: ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the [children] should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Loebel v. Loebel*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a child’s safety and well‑being are paramount in custody determinations and that the Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a showing of a material change of circumstances and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Loebel v. Loebel*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that the guiding principle in initial and modified custody determinations is the best interests of the child and cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 for the rule that modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances plus necessity in the child’s best interests. It further emphasizes children’s welfare (including safety from domestic violence) as paramount by requiring consideration of all relevant evidence, including abuse, when making custody decisions. Thus it squarely supports the proposition about best interests and modification standards in Massachusetts custody law.

*Adoption of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 573 (19.proposition: Massachusetts case law makes clear that where a parent’s conduct poses a potential danger to a child’s physical or emotional well‑being, the Court may impose restrictions on that parent’s custody or parenting time, including supervised visitation or conditions related to substance use.
*Adoption of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 573 (19.case_name: In Re the Department of Public Welfare to Dispense With Consent to Adoption
*Adoption of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 573 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a petition to dispense with parental consent to adoption and the standard of parental unfitness, not the imposition of custody/visitation restrictions such as supervised parenting time or substance‑use conditions. The only discussion of visitation appears in the remedial section, directing that visitation be reinstated unless it poses a serious threat, but the court does not develop or endorse a doctrine about tailoring custodial restrictions where a parent’s conduct poses potential danger. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about supervised visitation or substance‑related conditions.
*Adoption of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 573 (19.relevant_excerpt: The respondent’s visitation rights should be reinstated immediately and a visitation schedule established and continued until final determination of this case, unless it is determined by the court that such visitation will be, or is, a serious threat to the welfare of the child. It may be appropriate to hold a preliminary hearing to determine whether, through a gradual program of increased visitation, it would be feasible to return Shari to her natural mother without serious adverse effect, assuming, of course, that the respondent now appears to be otherwise fit.

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.proposition: Massachusetts case law makes clear that where a parent’s conduct poses a potential danger to a child’s physical or emotional well‑being, the Court may impose restrictions on that parent’s custody or parenting time, including supervised visitation or conditions related to substance use.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care and protection case in which the SJC affirms that, upon clear and convincing evidence of current parental unfitness and danger to children’s welfare, a judge may remove custody and commit children to the Department, which necessarily entails imposing severe restrictions on the parent’s custody and contact. The court also approves changing visitation from unsupervised to supervised after a risky incident (taking the child to a bar), reflecting judicial authority to structure visitation conditions to protect a child’s physical and emotional well‑being. The decision does not focus on substance‑use conditions, so that part of the proposition is only indirectly supported.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: “The removal of a child from the custody of his of her parent may be ordered only if there is clear and convincing evidence that the parent is currently unfit to care for that child… The judge’s findings are adequate under this standard to support the removal of the children from the mother’s care… On one occasion in October, 1981, visitation with Mary was changed from unsupervised to supervised status after the mother took Mary to a bar and restaurant.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts case law makes clear that where a parent’s conduct poses a potential danger to a child’s physical or emotional well‑being, the Court may impose restrictions on that parent’s custody or parenting time, including supervised visitation or conditions related to substance use.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on allocation of physical custody between parents and on removal of the children to Greece under a “best interests/real advantage” analysis. It does not discuss parental conduct that poses a danger to the child’s physical or emotional well‑being, nor does it authorize or even mention supervised visitation or substance‑use‑related conditions on custody or parenting time. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about imposing restrictions such as supervised visitation or substance‑use conditions.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations under the best‑interests standard and acknowledges that courts must consider whether a child’s living conditions adversely affect physical, mental, moral, or emotional health, but it does not involve or authorize restrictions such as supervised visitation or conditions tied to substance use. The case is about recognition of a California domestic partnership, legal parentage, and choice of primary physical custodian, not about imposing safety‑based restrictions on parenting time. It therefore does not directly support the specific proposition regarding supervised visitation or substance‑related conditions.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”
